article_title: After Michigan V. EPA, High Court Less Swayed By Chevron
article_text:
After Michigan V. EPA, High Court Less Swayed By Chevron

Law360, New York (July 10, 2015, 12:01 PM ET) -- On June 29, 2015, the U.S. Supreme Court issued an opinion in Michigan v. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency that could have serious implications for the EPA's ability to regulate hazardous air pollutant emissions from power facilities going forward, and on future EPA rule-making more generally.



Michigan v. EPA

article_metadata.description: The U.S. Supreme Court's ruling in Michigan v. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency can be read as the continuation of a trend away from Chevron deference to executive agency interpretations of statutory authority. In line with other recent decisions, such as King v. Burwell and Utility Air Regulatory Group v. EPA, Michigan suggests the EPA cannot count on receiving deference for statutory interpretations that significantly expand its regulatory reach, say attorneys at Jones Day.
